Linear Prediction based Data Detection of Convolutional Coded DQPSK in SIMO-OFDM

Vineel K Veludandi Dept. of Electrical Engineering
Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur
Kanpur, India 208016
Email: vineelkv@iitk.ac.in    K Vasudevan Dept. of Electrical Engineering
Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur
Kanpur, India 208016
Email: vasu@iitk.ac.in
Abstract

Data detection of convolutional coded differential quaternary phase shift keyed (DQPSK) signals using a predictive Viterbi algorithm (VA) based receiver, is presented for single input, multiple output - orthogonal frequency division multiplexed (OFDM) systems. The receiver has both error correcting capability and also the ability to perform channel estimation (prediction). The predictive VA operates on a supertrellis with just SST=SE×2P−1subscript𝑆STsubscript𝑆Esuperscript2𝑃1S_{\mathrm{ST}}=S_{\mathrm{E}}\times 2^{P-1} states instead of SST=SE×2Psubscript𝑆STsubscript𝑆Esuperscript2𝑃S_{\mathrm{ST}}=S_{\mathrm{E}}\times 2^{P} states, where the complexity reduction is achieved by using the concept of isometry (here SEsubscript𝑆ES_{\mathrm{E}} denotes the number of states in the encoder trellis and P𝑃P denotes the prediction order). Though the linear prediction based data detection in turbo coded OFDM [1] and the bit interleaved coded (BIC) OFDM [2] systems perform better than the proposed approach in terms of bit error rate (BER) for a given signal to noise ratio (SNR), the decoding delay of the proposed approach is significantly lower than that of the BIC and the turbo coded OFDM systems.

Index Terms:
Supertrellis, Prediction filter, Viterbi algorithm, Isometry.

I Introduction

OFDM has the ability to convert a frequency selective fading channel into a frequency flat channel [3]. Though the coherent detectors perform better than the linear prediction (LP)-based detectors in terms of BER [1, 4, 5], for a given SNR, coherent detectors are not throughput efficient since pilots have to be transmitted in every OFDM frame for the purpose of estimating the channel frequency response [6, 7, 8]. The throughput is defined as the ratio of the number of data symbols to the total symbols in an OFDM frame. However, since LP-based detectors perform data detection by using the channel statistics alone, LP-based detectors are throughput efficient since the statistics of the channel need to be estimated only once during the first OFDM frame [1]. In wireless communications, it is assumed that the channel statistics remain same for every OFDM frame but the channel impulse and frequency response changes with every OFDM.

In the proposed approach of LP-based data detection in convolutional coded SIMO-OFDM signals, the predictive VA operates on a supertrellis [9, 10, 1, 11, 12], obtained by combining the memory of the convolutional encoder and a prediction filter. A rate-1/2 convolutional encoder with SEsubscript𝑆ES_{\textrm{E}} states when combined with a prediction filter of order P𝑃P would result in a supertrellis with SE×2Psubscript𝑆Esuperscript2𝑃S_{\mathrm{E}}\times 2^{P} states. However, the complexity is reduced to just SE×2P−1subscript𝑆Esuperscript2𝑃1S_{\mathrm{E}}\times 2^{P-1} states using the concept of isometry [4, 1]. The channel prediction filter exploits the high degree of correlation in the channel frequency response at the output of the fast Fourier transform (FFT) in the OFDM receiver when the length of the channel impulse response is much smaller than the FFT length. Perfect timing and carrier synchronization is assumed. Simulation results are compared against the ideal coherent detector where perfect channel-state information (CSI) is assumed. It is shown that the LP-based receiver performs close to the ideal coherent receiver. Though the BER performance of the LP-based detection in bit interleaved coded (BIC) OFDM [2] and the turbo coded OFDM systems [1] perform better than the proposed approach, the decoding delay of the proposed approach is significantly lower than that of the BIC and the turbo coded OFDM systems.

This paper is organized as follows. The notation used throughput this paper is given in Section 2. The system model is given in Section 3. The proposed linear prediction-based receiver is discussed in Section 4. In Section 5, we give the simulation results. Finally in Section 6, we give the conclusion and the scope for the future work.

II Notation

In this paper, all lower-case and upper-case letters without a tilde e.g. gksubscript𝑔𝑘g_{k} represent real-valued scalar. Letters with a tilde e.g. h~ksubscript~ℎ𝑘\tilde{h}_{k}, denote complex quantities. However, complex symbols are denoted by Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} (without a tilde). Boldface letters represent vectors or matrices. All letters with a hat, e.g. X^ksubscript^𝑋𝑘\hat{X}_{k} denote the statistical estimate of X~ksubscript~𝑋𝑘\tilde{X}_{k} (or Xksubscript𝑋𝑘X_{k}, if it is real-valued). The (⋅)∗superscript⋅(\cdot)^{*} denotes complex conjugate, (⋅)ℋsuperscript⋅ℋ(\cdot)^{\mathscr{H}} denotes conjugate transpose and E​[⋅]𝐸delimited-[]⋅E\left[\cdot\right] denotes the expectation operation. We also assume that bit 00 maps to +11+1 and bit 111 maps to −11-1.

III System Model

III-A Transmitter

The binary input data gksubscript𝑔𝑘g_{k} (0≤k≤Ld/2−10𝑘subscript𝐿𝑑210\leq k\leq L_{d}/2-1) from the source are encoded using a rate-r1/r2subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2r_{1}/r_{2} convolutional encoder. The encoded data bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} is mapped to DQPSK according to the differential encoding rules [3] given in Table I to get Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}. The symbol stream Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} is fed to a serial to parallel converter (S/P) and loaded on to the OFDM sub-carriers by an Ldsubscript𝐿𝑑L_{d}-point inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) operation. The length of the cyclic prefix (CP) is equal to the length of the channel memory LCP=Lh−1subscript𝐿CPsubscript𝐿ℎ1L_{\textrm{CP}}=L_{h}-1 [3], and is inserted into the OFDM frame. Note that the overall rate of the transmitter in Figure 1 is 111, that is, one bit is sent per transmission. For every data bit, one coded QPSK symbol is transmitted, hence one bit of information is sent per transmission.

III-B Channel Model

We assume a Rayleigh frequency selective fading channel having a uniform power delay profile [13, 5, 14, 15, 16, 1]. Though an exponential power delay profile is more practical, we expect the uniform power delay profile to give the worst case BER performance since all channel taps (intersymbol interference (ISI) terms) have the same power. The channel is assumed to be time-invariant over each OFDM frame and varies independently from frame to frame i.e. quasistatic. For the lthsuperscript𝑙thl^{\mathrm{th}} diversity arm (0≤l≤Nr−10𝑙subscript𝑁𝑟10\leq l\leq N_{r}-1), the channel impulse response h~k,lsubscript~ℎ𝑘𝑙\tilde{h}_{k,l} (0≤k≤Lh−10𝑘subscript𝐿ℎ10\leq k\leq L_{h}-1) and AWGN noise w~k,lsubscript~𝑤𝑘𝑙\tilde{w}_{k,l} (0≤k≤Lf−10𝑘subscript𝐿𝑓10\leq k\leq L_{f}-1) are both wide-sense stationary (WSS) circularly symmetric complex Gaussian random variables with autocorrelation given by:

12​E​[w~k,l​w~k′,l′∗]12𝐸delimited-[]subscript~𝑤𝑘𝑙subscriptsuperscript~𝑤superscript𝑘′superscript𝑙′\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}{E}{\left[{\tilde{w}_{k,l}}{\tilde{w}^{*}_{k^{\prime},l^{\prime}}}\right]} ={σw2,if​ k=k’ and  l=l’ 0,otherwise.absentcasessubscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑤if k=k’ and  l=l’ 0otherwise\displaystyle=\begin{cases}\sigma^{2}_{w},&\text{if}$ {\it k=k'} \ and {\it\ l=l'} $\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases} (1)

Hence the autocorrelation needs to be estimated only once (see Section 4.1 in [1]). However, in this paper we assume that the receiver has perfect knowledge of the channel and noise statistics.

IV-A The Suboptimal Predictive Maximum Likelihood (ML) decoder [4]

The received signal at the lthsuperscript𝑙thl^{\mathrm{th}} diversity arm can be represented as:

Assuming that a Pthsuperscript𝑃thP^{\mathrm{th}}-order predictor completely decorrelates noise, (IV-A) can be written as

minq∑l=0Nr−1∑k=0P−1|z~k,l(q)|22​σe,k2+∑l=0Nr−1∑k=PLd−1|z~k,l(q)|22​σe,P2.subscriptmin𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑙0subscript𝑁𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑃1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝑧𝑘𝑙𝑞22subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑒𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑙0subscript𝑁𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑃subscript𝐿𝑑1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝑧𝑘𝑙𝑞22subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑒𝑃\displaystyle\mathop{\mathrm{min}}\limits_{q}\;\sum\limits_{l=0}^{N_{r}-1}\sum\limits_{k=0}^{P-1}\frac{\left|\tilde{z}_{k,\,l}^{\left(q\right)}\right|^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}_{e,\,k}}+\sum\limits_{l=0}^{N_{r}-1}\sum\limits_{k=P}^{L_{d}-1}\frac{\left|\tilde{z}_{k,\,l}^{\left(q\right)}\right|^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}_{e,\,P}}. (33)

Note that the first double summation in (33) denotes the “transient” part and the second double summation denotes the “steady state” part. Observe also that the predictor coefficients in (22) correspond to the autocorrelation of the channel frequency response. In practice, the predictor coefficients are obtained from the autocorrelation of X~k,lsubscript~𝑋𝑘𝑙\tilde{X}_{k,\,l}. Finally we note that the complexity in (33) increases exponentially with Ldsubscript𝐿𝑑L_{d}. In the Subsection IV-C, we present the predictive VA, whose complexity increases linearly with Ldsubscript𝐿𝑑L_{d}.

IV-B Supertrellis Construction [12, 1]

In Section IV (just after (7)), we mentioned that the symbols Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} are not known, and in practice they are obtained from a supertrellis. Consider the predictive VA in Figure 1. The inner decoder trellis must be modified to a supertrellis which incorporates the memory of the prediction filter.

Assume that the r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} coded bits from the inner rate-r1/r2subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2{r_{1}}/{r_{2}} convolutional encoder (in this work r1=1subscript𝑟11r_{1}=1,  r2=2subscript𝑟22r_{2}=2) are mapped111In this section we assume that the DQPSK mapper in Figure 1 is absent. The need to have a DQPSK mapper will be explained in Section IV-C1. to an M𝑀M-ary (M=2r2𝑀superscript2subscript𝑟2M=2^{r_{2}}) constellation according to the set partitioning rule, e.g. S0,j,h=ℳ​(𝒮0,j)subscript𝑆0𝑗ℎℳsubscript𝒮0𝑗S_{0,\,j,\,h}={\mathscr{M}}\left(\mathscr{S}_{0,\,j}\right) [3] (see Figure 2). Here, 𝒮0,jsubscript𝒮0𝑗\mathscr{S}_{0,\,j} (0≤𝒮0,j≤2r2−1)0subscript𝒮0𝑗superscript2subscript𝑟21\left(0\leq\mathscr{S}_{0,\,j}\leq 2^{r_{2}}-1\right) is the decimal equivalent of the n𝑛n coded bits bk​bk−1​…​bk−n+1subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘1…subscript𝑏𝑘𝑛1b_{k}b_{k-1}\ldots b_{k-n+1} in Figure 1, and is referred to as the input code digit. Note that since the supertrellis is a periodic structure, we have removed the subscript k𝑘k in Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} and replaced it with Si,j,hsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑗ℎS_{i,\,j,\,h}. The subscript “i𝑖i” in Si,j,hsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑗ℎS_{i,\,j,\,h} refers to the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\mathrm{th}} memory element of the prediction filter (the 0thsuperscript0th0^{\mathrm{th}} element is the input), the subscript “j𝑗j” refers to the present supertrellis state and “hℎh” denotes the next supertrellis state. Observe that the symbol sequence Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} in Figure 1 corresponds to one of the paths through the supertrellis.

Now consider Figure 3. Note that

{ℳ​(𝒮0,j),ℳ​(𝒮1,j),…,ℳ​(𝒮P,j)}ℳsubscript𝒮0𝑗ℳsubscript𝒮1𝑗…ℳsubscript𝒮𝑃𝑗\displaystyle\{\mathscr{M}\left(\mathscr{S}_{0,\,j}\right),\mathscr{M}\left(\mathscr{S}_{1,\,j}\right),\ldots,\mathscr{M}\left(\mathscr{S}_{P,\,j}\right)\} (34)

in Figure 3 is a valid encoded symbol sequence. In (34), the subscript P𝑃P refers to a Pthsuperscript𝑃thP^{\mathrm{th}}-order prediction filter and j𝑗j refers to the jthsuperscript𝑗thj^{\mathrm{th}} supertrellis state, as will be explained later.

Let SEsubscript𝑆ES_{\mathrm{E}} denote the number of encoder states. For any given present convolutional encoder state ℰisubscriptℰ𝑖\mathscr{E}_{i} (0≤i≤SE−1)0𝑖subscript𝑆E1\left(0\leq i\leq S_{\textrm{E}}-1\right), there are 2r1=Nsuperscript2subscript𝑟1𝑁2^{r_{1}}=N possible encoded symbols. Therefore, the total number of ways in which a Pthsuperscript𝑃thP^{\mathrm{th}}-order predictor can be populated is SE×NPsubscript𝑆Esuperscript𝑁𝑃S_{\mathrm{E}}\times N^{P} which is also equal to the number of supertrellis states. Therefore

SST=SE×NP.subscript𝑆STsubscript𝑆Esuperscript𝑁𝑃\displaystyle S_{\mathrm{ST}}=S_{\mathrm{E}}\times N^{P}. (35)

IV-C The Predictive Viterbi algorithm [5, 17, 3]

Let vk,m,nsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑚𝑛v_{k,\,m,\,n} denote the branch metric at time instant k𝑘k corresponding to the transition from state m𝑚m to state n𝑛n. We have

vk,m,nsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑚𝑛\displaystyle v_{k,\,m,\,n} =∑l=0Nr−1|z~k,m,n,l|2absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑙0subscript𝑁𝑟1superscriptsubscript~𝑧𝑘𝑚𝑛𝑙2\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{l=0}^{N_{r}-1}\left|\tilde{z}_{k,\,m,\,n,\,l}\right|^{2}
=∑l=0Nr−1|∑j=0Pa~P,j​Y~k−j,l/Sj,m,n|2absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑙0subscript𝑁𝑟1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑃subscript~𝑎𝑃𝑗subscript~𝑌𝑘𝑗𝑙subscript𝑆𝑗𝑚𝑛2\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{l=0}^{N_{r}-1}\left|\sum\limits_{j=0}^{P}\tilde{a}_{P,\,j}\tilde{Y}_{k-j,\,l}/S_{j,\,m,\,n}\right|^{2} (46)

where S0,m,nsubscript𝑆0𝑚𝑛S_{0,\,m,\,n} denotes the input symbol corresponding to the transition from state m𝑚m to n𝑛n and the data Sj,m,nsubscript𝑆𝑗𝑚𝑛S_{j,\,m,\,n} are the contents of the prediction filter of state m𝑚m.

IV-C1 Complexity Reduction using Isometry [1, 4, 5]

Consider the error signal z~k,m,n,lsubscript~𝑧𝑘𝑚𝑛𝑙\tilde{z}_{k,\,m,\,n,\,l} in (IV-C):

z~k,m,n,lsubscript~𝑧𝑘𝑚𝑛𝑙\displaystyle\tilde{z}_{k,\,m,\,n,\,l} =X~k,l−X^k,labsentsubscript~𝑋𝑘𝑙subscript^𝑋𝑘𝑙\displaystyle=\tilde{X}_{k,\,l}-\hat{X}_{k,\,l}
=∑j=0Pa~P,j​Y~k−j,lSj,m,nabsentsubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑗0subscript~𝑎𝑃𝑗subscript~𝑌𝑘𝑗𝑙subscript𝑆𝑗𝑚𝑛\displaystyle=\sum\limits^{P}_{j=0}\tilde{a}_{P,\,j}\frac{\tilde{Y}_{k-j,\,l}}{S_{j,\,m,\,n}}

Note that |z~k,m,n,l|2superscriptsubscript~𝑧𝑘𝑚𝑛𝑙2\left|\tilde{z}_{k,\,m,\,n,\,l}\right|^{2} is independent of S0,m,nsubscript𝑆0𝑚𝑛S_{0,\,m,\,n} (due to isometry [4]) and is dependent only on the phase changes between Sj,m,nsubscript𝑆𝑗𝑚𝑛S_{j,\,m,\,n} and S0,m,nsubscript𝑆0𝑚𝑛S_{0,\,m,\,n}. In particular, the all-zero and all-one sequence gksubscript𝑔𝑘g_{k}, yield the same magnitude squared error |z~k,m,n,l|2superscriptsubscript~𝑧𝑘𝑚𝑛𝑙2\left|\tilde{z}_{k,\,m,\,n,\,l}\right|^{2}, and are hence indistinguishable.

In general it is clear from (IV-C1) that two symbol sequences

𝐒(ν)={…​Sk−1(ν)​Sk(ν)​Sk+1(ν)​…}superscript𝐒𝜈…subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝜈𝑘1subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝜈𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝜈𝑘1…\displaystyle\mathbf{S}^{\left(\nu\right)}=\{\ldots S^{\left(\nu\right)}_{k-1}S^{\left(\nu\right)}_{k}S^{\left(\nu\right)}_{k+1}\ldots\} (48)

Now consider (IV-C1). Note that S0,m,n/S1,m,nsubscript𝑆0𝑚𝑛subscript𝑆1𝑚𝑛S_{0,\,m,\,n}/S_{1,\,m,\,n} is a function of the input code digit 𝒮0,jsubscript𝒮0𝑗\mathscr{S}_{0,\,j} in Figure 3 (see also Table I). Mathematically, this can be stated as

Thus the number of states in the trellis with differential encoding is only MP−1superscript𝑀𝑃1M^{P-1} instead of MPsuperscript𝑀𝑃M^{P}.

The VA operates as follows. Let 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛{\cal C}_{n} denote the set of states that converge to the state n𝑛n (0≤n≤SST−10𝑛subscript𝑆ST10\leq n\leq S_{\textrm{ST}}-1). Let μk,nsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑛\mu_{k,\,n} denote the path metric at time instant k𝑘k (0≤k≤Ld−10𝑘subscript𝐿𝑑10\leq k\leq L_{d}-1) and state n𝑛n.

  1. 1.

    Set initial values as k=0𝑘0k=0 and μ0,n=0subscript𝜇0𝑛0\mu_{0,\,n}=0 (0≤n≤SST−1)0𝑛subscript𝑆ST1\left(0\leq n\leq S_{\textrm{ST}}-1\right), since we assume that the receiver does not know the starting state.

  2. 2.

    Increase time k𝑘k by 1.

  3. 3.

    Compute the path metrics at each state n𝑛n as

    μk,n=minm∈𝒞n{vk,m,n+μk−1,m}.subscript𝜇𝑘𝑛subscriptmin𝑚subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝑣𝑘𝑚𝑛subscript𝜇𝑘1𝑚\displaystyle\mu_{k,\,n}=\mathop{\mathrm{min}}\limits_{m\in{\cal C}_{n}}\;\left\{v_{k,\,m,\,n}+\mu_{k-1,\,m}\right\}. (54)
    1. (a)

      Store the survivor for each state n𝑛n.

    2. (b)

      Identify the state having the minimum μk,nsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑛\mu_{k,\,n}, and trace back
      along the survivor path and release a symbol corresponding
      to time k−𝒟v′𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑣k-{\cal D}^{{}^{\prime}}_{v}, where 𝒟v′subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑣{\cal D}^{{}^{\prime}}_{v} is the decoding delay of the VA      .

    3. (c)

      Increase k𝑘k by 1.

    4. (d)

      Go to step 3 until time k=Ld𝑘subscript𝐿𝑑k=L_{d}.

V Simulation Results

Since the overall rate is 111, the average SNR per bit for each receive diversity arm is defined as [14, 15]:

SNR per bit =Nr×E​[|H~k,l​Sk|2]E​[|W~k,l|2]absentsubscript𝑁𝑟𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscript~𝐻𝑘𝑙subscript𝑆𝑘2𝐸delimited-[]superscriptsubscript~𝑊𝑘𝑙2\displaystyle=\frac{N_{r}\times{E}{\left[\left|\tilde{H}_{k,\,l}S_{k}\right|^{2}\right]}}{{E}{\left[\left|\tilde{W}_{k,\,l}\right|^{2}\right]}}
=Nr×(Lh×2​σf2)×|Sk|2Ld×2​σw2.absentsubscript𝑁𝑟subscript𝐿ℎ2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑓2superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘2subscript𝐿𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2\displaystyle=\frac{N_{r}\times\left(L_{h}\times{2\sigma_{f}^{2}}\right)\times\left|S_{k}\right|^{2}}{L_{d}\times{2\sigma_{w}^{2}}}. (55)

The simulation parameters are given in Table II. The BER performance of the linear prediction-based data detection in convolutional coded OFDM systems using predictive VA is given in Figure 4. The LP-based receiver for convolutional coded SIMO-OFDM performs close to the ideal coherent receiver.

VI Conclusion

We have shown that the LP-based receiver performs close to the ideal coherent receiver. Future work can be focused on increasing the bit rate using M𝑀M-ary constellations.
